description: From Middle English hardely, hardliche, from Old English heardlīċe (“boldly; hardily; without ease; in a way that causes pain; not easily; only by degrees”), equivalent to hard +‎ -ly. Compare Dutch hardelijk, German härtlich.

adverbs.description: hardly (comparative hardlier or more hardly, superlative hardliest or most hardly)

examples: they hardly ever watch television; I hardly think they'll come in this bad weather; it's hardly possible he could lose the election.
And what gentle flame soever doth warme the heart of young virgins, yet are they hardly drawne to leave and forgoe their mothers, to betake them to their husbands […].

entries.meaning: (manner, archaic) Harshly, severely; in a hard manner.
(manner, obsolete) Firmly, vigorously, with strength or exertion.
examples: Let him hardly be possest with an honest curiositie to search out the nature and causes of all things […].
